title: 107_s455
content: The Act titled "Encouraging Investment in Small Business Act" increases exclusion and makes modifications for qualified small business stock. The "Encouraging Investment in Small Business Act" increases the exclusion for gain from certain small business stock to 75 percent and reduces the holding period from 5 years to 3 years. Additionally, the Act repeals the minimum tax preference for items of tax preference. The "Encouraging Investment in Small Business Act" modifies the Internal Revenue Code by extending the working capital limitation from 2 years to 5 years and amending the assets treated as used in the active conduct of business. The "Encouraging Investment in Small Business Act" amends the Internal Revenue Code by extending the working capital limitation and modifying assets used in business. Additionally, it includes exceptions to redemption rules for stock purchases by corporations with a business purpose. The "Encouraging Investment in Small Business Act" amends the Internal Revenue Code by increasing the cap on eligible gain for joint returns and decreasing the capital gains rate. The "Encouraging Investment in Small Business Act" increases the cap on eligible gain for joint returns and decreases the capital gains rate. Additionally, it extends the rollover period for qualified small business stock. The "Encouraging Investment in Small Business Act" extends the rollover period for qualified small business stock from 60 days to 180 days. The amendments apply to stock issued after the date of the enactment of the Act, with a special rule for stock issued after August 10, 1993.
